citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The Bactrian camel has patchy hair loss with small abrasions on both sides of the body. The licensee stated that this
condition happens every spring. The licensee has not contacted the veterinarian concerning this hair loss.
Lack of contact with the veterinarian concerning veterinary issues with the animals leads to undiagnosed animal issues
and delayed treatment of illness and disease.
Each dealer or exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include daily observation
of all animals to assess their health and well-being; Provided, however, That daily observation of animals may be
accomplished by someone other than the attending veterinarian; and Provided, further, That a mechanism of direct and
frequent communication is required so that timely and accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior, and
well-being is conveyed to the attending veterinarian.
To be corrected by April 19, 2024

The licensee keeps large bales of hay, approximately four feet by eight feet, inside the shelter for the four goats, three
sheep and three equine species. One of the bales of hay has been eaten from the bottom and is very precariously tipped
forward, supported only by a single post, and could fall on an animal eating below.
Animals must be handled to minimize the possibility of trauma or physical harm.
Handling of all animals shall be done as expeditiously and carefully as possible in a manner that does not cause trauma,
overheating, excessive cooling, behavioral stress, physical harm, or unnecessary discomfort.
To be corrected by April 7, 2024.

The primary enclosure housing a single Bactrian camel has excessive mud, muck and standing water in it. There are
areas of the enclosure where the mud and water is approximately six to ten inches in depth. There is no dry area outside
of the shelter in the barn. The drinking water for the camel and the hay that is fed adlib are both outside of the shelter. The
camel has to walk through the mud and standing water to access water and hay.
Dry access to potable water and food is required to prevent soiling of the animals and to ensure they are eating and
drinking sufficiently to maintain good body condition, minimize disease hazards and maintain health.
A suitable method shall be provided to rapidly eliminate excess water. The method of drainage shall comply with
applicable Federal, State, and local laws and regulations relating to pollution control or the protection of the environment.
To be corrected by April 8, 2024

The water container for the Bactrian camel has brown/green organic material growing on the bottom and sides and
approximately one third of the top of the water receptacle has floating organic material floating on top of the water.
Lack of potable water can lead to dehydration of the camel which can further lead to disease or illness.
If potable water is not accessible to the animals at all times, it must be provided as often as necessary for the health and
comfort of the animal. Frequency of watering shall consider age, species, condition, size, and type of the animal. All water
receptacles shall be kept clean and sanitary.
To be corrected from this day forward April 5, 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
